Programming Locations.Zone Types: Location 25 - Segment 7 = 8, the rest donâ€™t matter
Programming Locations.Active Zones: Location 26 - Segment 7 = 1, the rest are blank

Commands.Fix Expander Error Code: Programming for device 0 and back out.

Customer Orientation.Smoke Detector Test: Demonstrate *7 (or menu 9 7) will reset smoke detectors
Customer Orientation.User Manual: Show page with smoke zone reset and trouble codes

Additional Features.Walk Test Mode: Press *, Chime, followed by user code

PC1616/PC1832.Enter programming: Press *8 followed by the installer code.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 009: Set PGM1 and PGM2 Type - 04 for 2-wire smoke detectors. Negative wire goes here.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 013: Options - Check number 4 and 8 for specific settings.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 015: Option 7 for dialer configuration - Check options 1 & 2.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 310: Account # - Use Fs to fill remaining.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 350: Set Contact ID - Option 3 for CID.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 377: Set for daily Timer Test - Enter 001, or 007 for weekly.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 380: Reporting codes - Should be 1,4,5. Option 1 for troubles.
PC1616/PC1832.Section 404: Panel Identification Code - Enter code such as 113200.
PC1616/PC1832.Time programming: Press [*] [6] [Master Code] [1] [HH:MM] [MM:DD:YY] to set military time and date.

DSC 1555 & PC5010.Enter Programming: Press *8 followed by the installer code.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Set PGM1 and PGM2 Type: 04 for 2-wire smoke detectors. Negative wire goes here.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Account Number: Use Fs to fill remaining in Section 310.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Contact ID Format: Enter account number for CID format in Section 311.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Set Contact ID: Set option 3 for CID in Section 350.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Timer Test: Set right 18 times to 001 for daily or 007 for weekly in Section 377.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Time for Test: Enter the time for the test in Section 378.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Troubles Reporting: Should be 1,4,5 with 1 for troubles in Section 380.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Phone Trouble: Options 1,2 indicate phone trouble in Section 401.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Panel Identification Code: Enter a specific code like 113200 in Section 404.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Wireless Programming: Refer to Section 804 for wireless device programming.
DSC 1555 & PC5010.Time Programming: To set the time, press [*] [6] [Master Code] [1] [HH:MM] [MM:DD:YY].

Trouble Conditions.CA: Alarm has been canceled by the customer (not a trouble).
Trouble Conditions.Dd: Phone test was sent okay (not a trouble).
Trouble Conditions.EA: An 'EA' or 'exit alarm' was triggered within 2 minutes of arming (not a trouble). This occurs when the system is still in its 'self check' mode.

1. Arrive.b: Tell them you just need to see the keypad.

2. Program.a: Enter programming by pressing the installer code then 800.
2. Program.c: If none of these work: Remove power from the system by disconnecting the battery and transformer, then reconnect and press * & # within 50 seconds of powering up.
2. Program.d: You should see '20' on the screen.
2. Program.e: Enter *20 4112 to set the installer code.
2. Program.f: Enter *41 with the primary phone number, *42 with the secondary phone number.
2. Program.g: After entering #43, note the account code.

3. Test.a: Ask the resident if you can use their cordless phone to test their system.
3. Test.b: Call the Gatehouse or 838-8275 and give them your name and the address where you are.
3. Test.c: Tell Security you are going to test the system.
3. Test.d: Warn the resident the siren will sound when you test the system.
3. Test.e: Take the phone off-hook so you hear the dial tone.
3. Test.f: Test the user code (e.g., Enter 1-2-3-4). If it doesn't work, ask the customer for the correct code.
3. Test.g: Press and hold the Fire panic button to send a fire signal.
3. Test.i: Press User Code + 1 to silence the siren.
3. Test.j: Call the Gatehouse and ask if they received an alarm.

4. Wrap-up.a: Inform the resident their system is programmed with a 10-digit phone number and it communicated with the Gatehouse.
4. Wrap-up.b: Inform them about the service charge of $50.
4. Wrap-up.d: Note the results of the test, including whether the phone line went dead (line seizure) and if the siren worked properly.

Programming Notes.Change House ID: Use Section 25 to change the house ID.
Programming Notes.Program Panic Buttons: Program panic buttons on the keypad for zones 95, 99, and 96 from top to bottom.
Programming Notes.Caller ID Configuration: Use location 48 for Caller ID configuration.
Programming Notes.Timer Test Setup: In the Scheduler, set up a 7-day timer test event 11 for all monitored systems. Set the installer code #64 on the highest number.
Programming Notes.Last Schedule Number: The last schedule numbers are 32 on 20P, 8 on a 15P.
Programming Notes.Periodic Timer Test: To turn on the periodic timer test, use location *64 1,0.

Twisted Pair.Description: Consists of a pair of insulated wires twisted together.
Twisted Pair.Applications: Used commonly in telecommunications and network cables like Ethernet.
Twisted Pair.Advantages: Reduces electrical interference and crosstalk between pairs.

Coaxial Cable.Description: Features a central conductor surrounded by an insulating layer, metallic shield, and an outer insulating layer.
Coaxial Cable.Applications: Used for cable television, internet, and CCTV installations.
Coaxial Cable.Advantages: Provides protection from electromagnetic interference, allowing for reliable data transmission over longer distances.
Coaxial Cable.Gauge: Common gauges include RG-6, RG-11, and RG-59.

Fiber Optic Cable.Description: Uses light to transmit data through strands of glass fibers encased in an insulated casing.
Fiber Optic Cable.Applications: Ideal for high-speed data transmission in telecommunications and network environments.
Fiber Optic Cable.Advantages: Provides extremely high bandwidth and low signal loss, suitable for long-distance communications.
Fiber Optic Cable.Considerations: More fragile than metal wiring and requires careful handling during installation.

Cat5e Cable.Description: Standard Ethernet cable providing speeds up to 1 Gbps at 100 MHz.
Cat5e Cable.Applications: Widely used in computer networking and other telecommunications.
Cat5e Cable.Advantages: Supports faster speeds compared to older Cat5, less crosstalk.
Cat5e Cable.Considerations: Limited to 100 meters for a single cable run without needing repeaters.

Cat6 Cable.Description: Improved version of Cat5e, offering speeds up to 10 Gbps at 250 MHz.
Cat6 Cable.Applications: Used in advanced computer networks, data centers, and where higher bandwidth is required.
Cat6 Cable.Advantages: Provides higher performance and is suitable for environments with higher electromagnetic interference.
Cat6 Cable.Considerations: More expensive than Cat5e; performance advantage can be significant depending on network needs and length of cable runs.

Siamese Cable.Description: Combines two cables, typically one coaxial and one power wire, physically and functionally bonded together.
Siamese Cable.Applications: Commonly used in CCTV installations to supply power and transmit video simultaneously.
Siamese Cable.Advantages: Simplifies installation by reducing the number of cables needed.
Siamese Cable.Considerations: Not as flexible as using separate cables; the combined structure may limit usage in some scenarios.

IP Cameras.Description: Internet Protocol cameras that send and receive data via a network and the internet.
IP Cameras.Common Uses: Commercial security, residential security, remote monitoring
IP Cameras.Advantages: Flexibility in installation, scalable, high-quality images

Analog Cameras.Description: Traditional CCTV cameras that use analog video signals to transmit images.
Analog Cameras.Common Uses: General surveillance in homes and businesses
Analog Cameras.Advantages: Cost-effective, simpler to set up and operate

PTZ Cameras.Description: Pan, Tilt, and Zoom cameras that offer wide area coverage and active monitoring.
PTZ Cameras.Common Uses: Large retail spaces, parking lots, large public areas
PTZ Cameras.Advantages: Coverage of large areas, can replace multiple fixed cameras

Thermal Cameras.Description: Use infrared radiation to create images and see through smoke, fog, and darkness.
Thermal Cameras.Common Uses: Perimeter security, search and rescue operations, industrial inspections
Thermal Cameras.Advantages: Detection in various weather conditions, non-visual monitoring

Wireless Cameras.Description: Cameras that transmit video and audio signals to a receiver through a radio band.
Features: No physical cable connection for video/audio transmission
Often battery-powered or with AC power adapters
Wireless Cameras.Common Uses: Home security, baby monitors, temporary surveillance setups

Voltage and Current Specifications.Understand the Specifications: Ensure compatibility of voltage and current requirements for all devices, typically within 12V or 24V systems.
Voltage and Current Specifications.Avoid Overloading: Ensure that the power supply and cables can handle the total current draw of all connected devices without exceeding capacity.

Cable Selection.Cable Type: Use appropriate cable types such as twisted pair, coaxial, Cat5e, or Cat6 based on the application's specific requirements.
Cable Selection.Cable Size: Select cable gauge based on current requirement and distance to minimize voltage drop. Use larger gauge wires for longer runs.

Wiring Practices.Color Coding: Adhere to standard color coding for wires to ensure consistent and safe connections.
Wiring Practices.Proper Labeling: Label all cables at both ends to simplify maintenance and troubleshooting.

Safety.Insulation and Protection: Ensure all wiring is properly insulated and, where necessary, protected by conduits or cable management systems to prevent physical damage.
Safety.Check Regulations: Comply with local codes and regulations for low voltage installations to ensure safety and legality.

Installation Techniques.Avoid Electrical Interference: Run low voltage cables away from high voltage power lines to prevent electromagnetic interference.
Installation Techniques.Secure Connections: Ensure all connections are secure and properly terminated to avoid loose connections that could lead to failures or safety issues.

EventsLeadingToOSHAct.Details: Caused a crisis in workplace safety and health conditions.
Additional laws increased the federal government's role in job safety and health.

Coverage.Includes: All private sector employers and their workers in the 50 states and all territories and jurisdictions under federal authority
Excludes: Immediate members of farming families not employing outside workers
Workers covered by other federal agencies such as mine workers, certain truckers, and atomic energy workers
Public employees in state and local governments except in states with their own plans

Mission.Description: To assure the safety and health of American Workers.
Activities: Develops job safety and health standards
Provides training programs to increase knowledge
Operates OSHA-approved job safety and health programs in states with approved plans

Rights: Raise a safety or health concern with your employer or OSHA, or report a work-related injury or illness, without being retaliated against
Right to a Safe and Healthful Workplace as specified under the General Duty Clause

Requirements: Means to inform workers of the hazards of non-routine tasks

Must: Provide a workplace free from recognized hazards
Comply with occupational safety and health standards
Provide training, exposure records, and safety data sheets to employees

Changes.Details: Chemical manufacturers and importers must determine the hazards of the chemicals they produce or import

Sections.Additional: Ecological information, Disposal considerations, Transport information, Regulatory information, Other information including the date of preparation or last revision

Definition.Identity: The unique identifier for any person or object, distinguishing them within a system.
Definition.Authentication: The process by which a system validates an identity, typically through credentials like passwords, biometric data, or other security tokens.
Definition.Authorization: Determines what an authenticated identity is allowed to do within a system, specifying access levels and permissions.

PhysicalWorld.Description: An official document issued by a government, certifying the holder's identity and citizenship.
A legal authorization issued by a state that allows an individual to operate one or more types of motorized vehicles.
Identification used primarily for healthcare professionals and staff within hospital facilities.

DigitalWorld.Description: A digital identity created in Microsoft's Azure AD, which manages and secures identities.
A digital record that provides authorization to use a software product.
A unique identifier associated with an email account.

PhysicalWorld.Description: A physical metal tool that opens a lock to a residence.
A physical or digital document that grants holder access to an event.
A numeric or alphanumeric code used to gain entry through a secure gate.
A card that provides electronic access to a locked area.

DigitalWorld.Description: A cryptographic key used for secure remote login protocols.
A digital certificate that authenticates a website's identity and enables an encrypted connection.
A password that protects email accounts from unauthorized access.
A secret used to protect API security or application authentication states.
A security token that grants limited access to resources in a storage account.
A card embedded with a chip that stores digital access rights.

MicrosoftEntra.Description: A new product family that includes all of Microsoft's identity and access capabilities, including Azure AD, Permissions Management, and Verified ID.

Components.Name: Azure Active Directory
Components.Description: Designed for cloud-enabled devices, services, and platforms, supporting modern office solutions and web technologies.

Components.Name: Azure AD Domain Services
Components.Description: Provides managed domain services such as domain join, LDAP, group policy, and authentication with a cloud-native approach.

Lessons.Details: Focuses on the differences and uses of Azure AD vs traditional Active Directory.
Explores the transition from legacy systems to modern authentication protocols and practices.

ZeroTrustSecurity.Concept: Trust no identity by default, regardless of the network origin. Use rigorous identity verification and access controls.

Implementation.Description: Requires users to provide multiple pieces of evidence before gaining access.
Policies to grant or block access based on user, location, device health, and other factors.

CableInfrastructure.ChurnRate: Detailed churn rate data not provided
CableInfrastructure.IntegratedInfrastructure: Details about outsourcing building management and structured cabling architecture
CableInfrastructure.CampusInfrastructure: Details about the backbone connections linking entrance facilities, equipment rooms, and telecommunications rooms
CableInfrastructure.HorizontalCabling: Connects to outlets on the floor or in the ceiling in Work Areas (WA's)

WorkArea.Description: Area where one person normally works, defined as 10sq meters
WorkArea.MUTOA: Multi-user Telecommunications Outlet Assembly, typically from 6-24 ports
WorkArea.FTTE: Fiber to the Enclosure - Fiber runs up the riser from the equipment room, through the TR to a Telecom Enclosure in an office area

CableCharacteristics.CrossConnect: Refers to the patch across or between two panels to make a port active as required
CableCharacteristics.NEXT: Near End Crosstalk - Leakage of signal from the transmitter pair to a receiver pair at the same end, expressed in dB
CableCharacteristics.FEXT: Far End Crosstalk - Undesired signal coupling at the far end of the cable
CableCharacteristics.ACR-N: Attenuated signal to Near-end Crosstalk Ratio, expressed in dB
CableCharacteristics.ACR-F: Far-end Crosstalk Level, expressed in dB
CableCharacteristics.PropagationDelaySkew: Time it takes for a signal to propagate from one end to the other, expressed in nanoseconds
CableCharacteristics.NVP: Nominal velocity of propagation - The speed of the signal through a specific cable type relative to the speed of light, specified in percentages
CableCharacteristics.Impedance: Characteristic impedance & Return Loss measured in Ohms along the link

FiberOptics.CoreSize: 8-9 microns for single mode, 50 or 62.5 microns for multimode

Types.SingleMode: Used for long-distance communication with lower attenuation and higher bandwidth
Types.Multimode: Used for shorter distances, supporting data rates up to 100 Gbps over short distances

SafetyClasses.Class3R: Low risk to eyes, suitable for certain controlled environments
SafetyClasses.Class3B: Moderate risk, requiring safety measures against direct eye exposure
SafetyClasses.Class4: High risk, capable of causing damage to skin and eyes, safety controls required

SafetyStandards.ANSI_TIA_569: Regulations for cable installation, including bend radius and proximity to lighting
SafetyStandards.Handling: Guidelines for maximum pulling tension, bending, and exposure to elements

Definition.Description: A facility that houses interconnected data processing, storage, and communications assets.
Definition.Includes: Rack or cabinet-mounted equipment and structured cabling systems.
Definition.Requirements: High reliability, security, self-contained environment with power and redundancy.
Definition.EnvironmentalSystems: HVAC (Heating, Ventilation, and Air Conditioning) especially cooling.
Definition.GlobalNetworks: Supports global networks with multiple sites for regional efficiency and redundancy.

Processors.Description: Includes CPUs and rack-mounted servers, forming the core of data center operations.
Processors.Connectivity: Connected via LAN or SAN using fiber or copper cabling.

Switches.Description: Includes director class, core, aggregation, and edge switches, routers, and hubs for remote access.

Storage.Description: Disk, solid state, NAS, and tape storage systems for long-term backups and central databases.

Structure.Components: Consists of computer rooms and service spaces, adhering to standards-based area notations.

ConnectivityRequirements.HighDensity: Equipment needs to be easily rack-mounted and accessible.
ConnectivityRequirements.Flexibility: Design should allow for upgrades and fast installation.
ConnectivityRequirements.CablingInfrastructure: Crucial for linking communications, video, building automation, and external networks.

Servers.Description: Provide applications like email and web hosting.

BladeServers.Description: Minimize space by sharing common components, mounted in a chassis.

Virtualization.Definition: Running multiple applications and operating systems on one server.
Virtualization.Benefits: Reduces physical devices, energy, heat dissipation, and cabling needs.
Virtualization.Cabling: Higher grade cabling required for increased data traffic.

DAS.Description: Directly attached storage to one computer, not accessible by others.

NAS.Description: Has its own network address, offering superior connectivity and performance.

SAN.Description: High-speed network of shared storage devices.

NASLocation.Description: NAS can be located outside data centers.

NetworkBandwidth.Description: Ensure sufficient network bandwidth and plan for scalability.

NASGateway.Description: Uses SAN or attached disk arrays for larger storage capacities.
NASGateway.Advantage: Not limited by the capacity of the appliance itself.

Infiniband.Description: InfiniBand is an industry standard interconnect technology for data centers and high performance computing and is a switched fabric I/O (Input/Output) technology that ties together servers, storage devices, and network devices.
Infiniband.ChannelCreation: InfiniBand channels are created by attaching host channel adapters (HCAs) and target channel adapters (TCAs) through InfiniBand switches. HCAs are I/O engines located within a server. TCAs enable remote storage and network connectivity into the InfiniBand interconnect fabric.
Infiniband.LinkPerformance: InfiniBand architecture offers three levels of link performance with higher data rate channels appearing in commercial use, allowing further increase in throughput.

CablingMedia.CopperUsage: Used over short distances, typically less than 15 meters, at very high bandwidth.

Ethernet.Description: Ethernet is a set of frame-based computer networking technologies designed for Local Area Networks (LANs). It defines wiring and signaling standards for the Physical Layer of the OSI model and a common addressing format.
Ethernet.IEEE802.3: The IEEE 802.3 standards address the requirements for all Ethernet data rates.
Ethernet.DataRates: Ethernet protocols range in data rate from 10Mb/s to 100Gb/s with other data rates in draft form.
Ethernet.MediaTypes: Ethernet can run over a range of media types. 10Gb interfaces are available over copper cables up to 100m, with higher speeds of 40Gb and 100Gb achieved using fiber cable.

FiberRequirements.OM3/4/5: Laser optimized fiber for faster interfaces.

StorageAndFiberChannel.Description: Fiber Channel was developed to support SCSI operations across a fiber-based network and can be supported across copper cabling via iSCSI.
StorageAndFiberChannel.iSCSIProtocol: Internet Small Computer System Interface (iSCSI) allows connecting iSCSI storage directly into the corporate IP network (LAN).
StorageAndFiberChannel.iSCSIUsage: With iSCSI technology, data center LANs and SANs can be converged to the same type of network - 10GBASE-T Ethernet IP.

FiberChannelOverEthernet.Description: FCoE allows for FC data to be encapsulated in Ethernet frames and delivered to a host via a single Converged Network Adapter.
FiberChannelOverEthernet.Advantages: Reduces the number of cables required to connect to servers.

NetworkArchitectures.ToRConverged: Top of Rack (ToR) converged setup used with FCoE.

Servers.Connectivity: Multiple connections including SAN (Fiber Channel) and LAN (Ethernet RJ45).

Storage.DiskUsage: Dominant storage method on the SAN.
Storage.TapeAdvantages: High speed performance, high capacity, lower cost, reduced energy costs, portability.

Fiber.LC: Duplex format for applications up to 10G.
Fiber.MPO: Multi-fiber connectors with 12 fibers, with newer 16 fiber MPOs increasing density and speeds.

InfrastructureEvolution.TopologyChanges: From individual copper cables to multi-fiber trunk cables and patch panels.
InfrastructureEvolution.IntelligentInfrastructures: IIS - Intelligent Infrastructure Solutions providing visibility, management, accuracy, service provisioning, and security.

GeneralTrendsAndIssues.Description: Increasing availability of inexpensive high-density servers requiring more power, cooling, and structured cabling. Consolidation of servers, storage, and information management.
GeneralTrendsAndIssues.Virtualization: Storage and servers seen as abstract resources by operating systems or clients.
GeneralTrendsAndIssues.TierRatings: Focus on 'tier' level ratings defining extremely robust, limited downtime designs. The Uptime Institute provides unbiased advisory, innovation, collaboration, and certifications.

UptimeInstituteTierLevels.Considerations: Increased awareness of security, terrorism, natural disasters, and vulnerability of commercial power. Designing infrastructure to Uptime Institute tier levels.

GrowthRatesAndOperationalSavings.GrowthRates: Difficult to calculate; explosive growth could lead to inadequate capacity or infrastructure, forcing upgrades or replacement.
GrowthRatesAndOperationalSavings.OperationalSavings: Realized through data center consolidation, less real estate, management, and life cycle linked to infrastructure and electronics. Automation reduces operational costs and downtime.

DataCenterLayout.Definition: Includes the Computer room, Entrance room, Telecom room, Office, Network Operations Center (NOC), and Support rooms.
DataCenterLayout.Integration: Electrical, environmental, telecommunications, and access systems must be integrated for effective service over the facility's life.
DataCenterLayout.Optimization: Systems must be optimized for long-term and short-term service reliability.

DesignConsiderations.WellIntegratedCabling: Designers must work closely with facility engineering groups. For smaller data centers, select floors close to ground level and locate equipment rooms near electrical and telecommunications facilities.
DesignConsiderations.FlowOptimization: Optimize the flow of electrical power, environmental equipment, and spaces. Consider future plans and customer migration strategies.

AdditionalAreasAndRooms.ElectricalRoom: Holds switchgear, Uninterruptible Power Supplies (UPS), and backup facilities.
AdditionalAreasAndRooms.LoadingDockAndStorage: Should be adjacent to the data center for easy access. Consider staging/unpacking areas.
AdditionalAreasAndRooms.HVAC: Requires large boiler and cooling room areas.
AdditionalAreasAndRooms.ServerAndNetworkBuildAreas: Dedicated area for IT staff to unpack, set up, pre-configure, and test equipment.

NetworkArchitecture.Plan: Establishes necessary equipment and cabling links. Provides access to the Internet, network connections to multiple carriers, and firewalls for protection.
NetworkArchitecture.CoreRouters: Two (or more) core routers for load sharing, redundancy, and rapid failover. Current speeds: OC48 or OC192 for larger IDCs, OC3 or OC12 for smaller DCs.
NetworkArchitecture.FirewallAppliances: Examine higher TCP/IP protocol levels to block illegitimate access and protect data. Use multiple stacked firewalls for load sharing.

RedundancyAndFailover.AccessSwitches: Utilized in pairs for redundancy and load sharing.
RedundancyAndFailover.ServerInterfaces: Most servers, switches, and firewalls use Gigabit Ethernet interfaces. High-performance storage array-based servers use 10 Gigabit Ethernet.
RedundancyAndFailover.SAN: Solutions use Gigabit Ethernet and Fiber Channel options.

DMZAndInternalNetwork.DMZ: Protected by a first bank of firewalls, handles corporate web presence and online business applications.
DMZAndInternalNetwork.InternalNetwork: Protected by a second bank of firewalls, provides access to proprietary information and the DMZ.
DMZAndInternalNetwork.VPNs: Set up through the network or alongside it for remote locations.

AdvancedServices: Command Center or Network Operations Center (NOC)
HostingCenters.Caching: Web pages copied for redundancy and quicker access.
HostingCenters.VPNs: Provide customers with 'backend' private connections to their servers.

PowerAndCooling.PowerDensity: Increasing level of power density and demands for more circuits and capacity.
PowerAndCooling.CoolingDensity: Increasing level of heat density and cooling efficiency optimization.

BuildingServiceRequirements.CostDrivers: Business drivers like availability, efficiency, and cost reduction are driving technology trends and infrastructure optimization.

Tier1And2.UPSAndPDUs: Key subsystems. Power delivery sequence: utility company -> facility switchgears -> UPSs -> PDUs -> IT loads.

PowerArchitecture.Considerations: Clean and uninterrupted electrical power essential. Consider neighbors sharing your feeder and install transient voltage surge suppression (TVSS) at every level.

RedundantPower.UPSAndGenerators: Combination provides the best protection. UPS systems provide immediate power, generators provide long-term power.

Generators.Diesel: Preferred for long-term power. Regular checks for microbial growth and solutions for low temperature gelling needed.

PowerDistributionUnits.PDUs: Provide clean current and should be installed for each horizontal distribution area. Ideally, one PDU per two aisles.

PowerUsageEffectiveness.PUE: Facility-level power efficiency index. PUE = Total Facility Power / IT Equipment Power.
PowerUsageEffectiveness.DCiE: Alternative metric describing power efficiency as a percentage.

GreenGridGuidelines.Purpose: Lower energy usage provides lower operational costs and is environmentally friendly.
